steps.title: Getting Started with Codenvy
steps.content:
Codenvy is a crazy fast, no-thrashing cloud IDE. Code, build, run and share projects from within your browser. Craft your finest code then command non-blocking, non-thrashing Docker microservices with access to (mostly) infinite resources to perform builds and runs.

This guided tour introduces Codenvy’s capabilities. It will take 3 minutes to complete.

If you need help contact us on our [https://groups.google.com/a/codenvy.com/forum/#!forum/codenvy Google Forum]. This is a temporary workspace. Your work will be lost if you are idle for 10 minutes. [https://codenvy.com/site/create-account Sign up for a free account] to save your work.

steps.title: Run the app
steps.content: Let’s start by running the app.  We simplify your work by building the application, downloading dependencies and configuring the app’s runner environment (including RAM and queues) automatically.

steps.title: Preview the app
steps.content:
Codenvy launches a Docker container for each run. Docker containers are isolated processes with the software to run your code.  Your project’s code and artifacts are copied into the runner automatically.  When the runner has finished loading, the application preview URL will appear.  Clicking the URL will view the application in a new browser tab. Console applications will display output in the console panel.
Click the URL here to see the application.

steps.title: Access the Terminal
steps.content: Every Codenvy runner has a terminal with root access. Try it by typing “top” to get a list of your running processes.

steps.title: Edit the app
steps.content: The editor includes key bindings for emacs, vi, and sublime along with syntax highlighting, auto-complete, error warnings, quick-fix, code folding, and international keyboard support.   You can change keybindings in the Window -> Preferences.

steps.title: See your Change
steps.content: Testing your change is as easy as re-running the app.  Now let’s check out the git integration.

steps.title: Git Integration
steps.content: Codenvy projects may have a local git or subversion repository. The git and svn plugins provide visual access to commands.  From this menu you can add to indexes, commit changes, pull and push.

steps.title: Temporary Workspace
steps.content: This project has been created in a temporary workspace which has 512MB of RAM. Your project will be destroyed if you close the tab or become idle.  We’ll guide you through importing and sign-up.

steps.title: Import your Projects
steps.content: You can import projects from external locations. Create a free account to get a named workspace with unlimited private projects, then link your Github credentials (or any of 15 other providers we support).
